name: Shadowlords, Dreamcatcher & Demon - Adam Miller's Campaign
author: Noctem

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hi All,

Unlike most, if not all, threads in this section, I'm not here to recommend the campaign - yet, anyway. I have but recently downloaded these modules, and have some questions. Hopefully, others in the Guild will be able to help furnish answers. That way, if the campaign's any good, those of us uninitiated in SDD (acceptable shorthand?) will be able to travel together through it with a mentor or two in tow - not in a walkthrough kind of way, but more one of issues, cries for help, etc.

Discussions around the campaign started here.

Do please ignore the first blatherings thereon, they have naught to do with this. I start annoying people with questions about this campaign at about contribution #10. My current outstanding question (not a quality judgement) being whether SDD is Dev Crit enabled or not? I'll be assuming normal (OC) NwN1 rules, classes, etc apply in un-nerfed fashion unless told otherwise. I just don't really want to spend time building something that I'll have to change once I've hit epic levels and realise some of the feats I've chosen are redundant (yes, Great Cleave, I'm looking at you).

In any event, I hope the Empyres, Valerfors and such luminaries (I discounted Hip, as a mostly PW or PnP player, though any input from him would, of course, be welcome) will occasionally cast their eyes this way. Or, it could all go to the Abyss...

edit: per Hip, furnished jump-over link to Neverwinter Vault project and onwards; 20160724

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: This campaign ends at about the same level as the OC, so Dev Crit is not possible. I just looked to confirm that I remember correctly, and my last saved game in my only play-through so far in Demon is at level 16. I don't remember anything being nerfed.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks Empyre - that's both helpful and annoying. Helpful because it fully answers my question. Annoying because for some reason I'd got it in my head that the full campaign took you into the 30s. That said, presumably on completion one's build can then be carried across elsewhere. But if that doesn't float your boat, one need only design a character to max-out between levels 16 and 18, which actually might be very useful for fledgling builders - particularly given the campaign's reputed low-med magic environment, so it ain't all about the gear.

Also thanks to Hip for tidying up my first post - much purtier, and appreciated!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I think I've settled on my first toon to blaze a trail in this unexplored territory. I reckon my building skills still need some work, so I'll go with something tried and tested first, just to get a feel for the place. And lo, there was Mick Dagger's Brawler Champion snoozing in the Level 20 section of the Guild! As one given more to the un-arcane arts, a Fighter 8/Monk 2/CoT 10 build looks ideal: good saves, decent AC and AB, lovely. Thanks Mick! Just going to fire it up now. This does mean I'll be playing two different Aielund campaigns and this one simultaneously, but variety's the spice of life, right?

I should have got the hang of making my links succinct and elegant by now, but I haven't, so this is it: http://nwnecbguild.forumer.com/topic/23 ... 5YUixJnEqg

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Okay, have got my first quest (hard to avoid it, really) and my first question. Henchmen/companions: worthwhile? And if so, how many can/should you take, and what's the AI like? I'm not asking who to take with me, 'cause I guess that's a judgement call, depending on one's own build, play-style and alignment. I've already got Nooble, but may have to drop him - he too is a meleer, and has a ridiculous name to boot - depending on any answers to the questions above, because I've just met a Rogue (albeit a crap one - she got caught and wants me to pay her fine) and they're always handy to have around. As a predominantly melee player, I'm always on the lookout for someone who can either stop me from exploding or kiss it better when I do!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: I have played this campaign and Saleron's Gambit only once each, and I'm afraid my memories of the two are getting intermingled. I do remember that Demon assumes that the PC and the hench of the opposite sex have become a couple, but I seem to recall a female Cleric, not a Rogue. Maybe you meet her in a later chapter? I think you are allowed only one hench. I'm sorry that my memory of this is so hazy.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Sorry for being late to the party...

a) There are both there, both are female, one is a rogue the other is a "celestial being" but a cleric non-the-less. Both are romantic options for a player character. Both will bestow some small "gifts" to your character and they also have some small power-ups intertwined to the story for them. And if you dont have Tony's AI both of them are going to suck big time but at least if i remember correctly default Linu's is better than default Tommu's but whatever, It is ultimately an RP choice. And there is always Noober ;)

b) There are only two campaigns that will take you to the high thirtie's lvl. Sands of Fate and Aielund. Unless you want to enter a random dungeon generator module (i don't remember the name but Mick was used to play one if i recall correctly). And there was an arena-type module (very old) that pitted the HoF builds Vs your PC. All the other choices will bring you up to high twentie's - thirty lvl maximum. That is why in old times there was a thread that specified a path that your hero could take with the same character and take them to high lvls, but still not forty. It was named "The Heroe's Path" you can google it and find out more about it. It basically linked similar modules for your character to take that made sense.

c) These small campaigns that finish before twenty lvl or slightly above it, and are of low to medium magic, are perfect opportunities for you to play somethiing that isn't a straight melee build. Try playing a wizard or bard in those module paths is also a very good choice because the power  lvl of your magic will be stronger, far stronger than the items sold in there. Most people who played Saleron's Gambit for example said (comments from the old nwnVault) that playing a wizard/ bard there, was a superb experience compared to a fighter. I guess Adam Miller's campaign will be similar in that regard.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks, both - and grand to see Valerfor peering over the fence ("Are you going to throw rocks at me now?" - Noober)

A few things...bugger me for a pound of marmalade, but the first time I've taken a female PC into a new campaign is the exact one where I'm presented with only female romance options. Brilliant. Secondly, given the likelihood of only one companion, it'll either be the rogue or the healer, given my proclivities. And yes, I know I really should practice taking some arcane classes, but not on my first run-through, eh? Sometimes I think you're just trying to improve me, and that would never do . I haven't met the "celestial being" yet (Valerfor, are you sure you're not thinking of Nellise in Aielund?), I've only just appeared on the streets of Scornubel. Poor old Nooble, shortest henchman career ever (ie, simply walking out of the door).

"What about now?"
"What about now?"
"What about now?"...ad infinitum

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
If your PC is female, Nooble is your love interest. My female PC had developed quite a friendship with Anera, but then when Demon started, I was suddenly switched to Nooble as if he had always been my hench.

A melee Cleric would do well in the Adam Miller campaign. In fact I have already played one in Saleron's Gambit, and I have one planned for Adam miller's campaign, too. You buff up before a fight and then fight as if you were a regular melee type. Just make sure not to wait until the fight has already begun before you buff, and if you have buffs to spare, buff your hench too.

Stagmeister wrote:
From all I've read, Battle Clerics are pretty awesome anywhere, and I will try one out soon, just not in my first run-through.
Don't be a weeny, Stagmeister.  Play your first serious self-buffer.  Not only will you broaden your experience before the fated aneurysm occurs, but you will learn first-hand what you will face with your head-basher vs. a fully-fledged priest. Go for the gusto, dammit!

The best experience (IMHO) is playing new content in total darkness.  Pure adventure. That's what the designer intended with all his hard labor, to test your competence and ingenuity.  Tips are vastly over-rated for the true AD&D fan.

I like the way you grabbed both Cleave and IKD in 20 levels with so few Ftr, Empyre. Very efficient and solid skill set.  DP exploitation.  A full Monty of spells.  What more could you want?

The only changes I would make would be a juggling of feats.  I like to have empowered abilities ready to go as soon as the slots open up at Clc 7,  yet not delay KD too long.  Lvl 6 Empower; Lvl 12 Blind Fight, Lvl 15 IKD... with those extra 18 HPs delayed until Lvl 18 if they really matter. I would have gone with Lightning Reflexes plus Empowered Cat's/AoV (Yah,  I recommend War swap for Magic) will bring those reflexes up to a more respectable level.  AoV is handy to have when allied.  You get nice party boosts without needing to buff them separately.  Battle Mastery will replace the lost DR spell from Magic.

Actually, that could have been built better, though not for all of the reasons mentioned.  DP, except for the HP boost, becomes worthless in a STR build over BAB 15. That build, though played through well into epic on a medium magic server, was more theme-based than it was optimized for combat.  About the only early buffs that will help unarmed attacks are Div Favor and Empowered Bull STR and (with all due respect to Mr. Dagger), screw those blasted kamas! I mean, that was the main impetus of building a fister in the first place.  IMO, kamas should either be DW'd or ignored and there are plenty of dual kama battle priest builds out there to chose from, both damage adepts and DevCrit variants. Prayer and Battletide afford the same attack/dmg/save benefits regardless of caster level, with fists or kama.

Unarmed monks can be tough to compete when glove enhancements are limited or because the fists just can't penetrate DR without GMW even though the bludgeoning has some perks vs. skels.  But the stun factor is VERY nice, prebuffed with Empowered Owl... as is the immunity to disarm.  This build was contrived mainly for those wanting to reap many of the monk goodies and sick of always building a predictable and typecast monk attack.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
What you need to grasp from examining Max's builds is that they are all about sheer power (hence the term "power-build").   He doesn't mind wading into the fray, as overwhelming as it might appear, and then depending on his intrinsic build characteristics to dominate any encounter to the best his design has to offer.  In other words, he doesn't mind dying occasionally if he is getting a buzz from the build's inherent strengths.  That's why you don't see him playing archers or sneakers (well, at least I never have) or building them.  Just too tactical and time-consuming for his style.  After all, there are many more builds for him to devise and play, eh?

I, on the other hand, am all about strategy and controlling the environment.  I am a huge proponent of recon and will scout unfamiliar areas under invisibility or GS (or via possessed familiar, as applicable) until I am satisfied that as many variables as possible have been identified.  Death is never part of the equation for me and never accepted.  That comes from playing several permadeath PWs that I thoroughly enjoyed.  In SP, you can always reload but on-line play is a whole other ball of wax.  Additionally, if my toon serves as a support member, I take it personally if my actions (or inactions) contribute to any other members suffering a fate that could well have been avoided with some more prudent preparation.  But server play is like SP on steroids.  It moves VERY fast because your partymates are always displacing in directions unanticipated and generally in a hurry to reach the goal.  That's in some degree due to the limited amount of time players can arrange to play in a single session.

I've used several of Max's contrivances but never "as is".  That's what you will need to refine.  Recognize your own playstyle, what is comfortable, then make alterations to well-established builds to better suit your biases.  Early on, you will be guessing at what might work for you. Eventually, you will follow a regimen closer to my own where one simply builds complete from scratch and then starts examining similar builds using the search engine.  9 times out of 10 I will discover a nuance in other builds, certain feat selections, a different ability spread, a racial variant, et al. that I may have glossed over and which would improve on my own ideas.  The real gems are all the input in the discussion where players elaborate on their own experience using varying techniques of each build's forte.  Essentially, it's the difference between theory and application.  One looks good on paper but the other involves interaction with the specific environment.

And yes... Mick is EVIL by nature!

Nah. The tougher it is, the faster you'll learn. All the OC does is show a new player how to use the game interface. Combat situations are pitifully pedestrian and actually encourage bad habits.  Stick with it. Be resourceful.

First off, what toon level?  I'm assuming a cleric 1 with at least 16 WIS.  You should be slotting Magic Weapon, Shield of Faith and either Bless or Div Favor.  If they have them and can afford them, use Bless/Aid pots and slot DF instead of Bless.  By cleric 2, Bless duration will be double Div Favor but you'll have the extra slot.  If you are really struggling, slot a summon.  If there are skels/zombies, try turning them before moving into melee.  Worse case scenario, slot all 3 summons to tank, pick up an xbow and snipe until your cleric gains some more prowess and HP. So what build did you finally settle on so we can follow in our playbooks?

A key module question:  What are the rest restrictions, if any?

2nd question: What domains did you select?
And second: is it right that I'm getting no xp from killing things? Quests and so on, fine, but nowt at all?
 
Didn't know if this series used that system, too.  Almraiven is pretty much played this way, with most all XP coming from quest's completion (and there are piles of those) with the combat relegated to just an obstacle to survive.  If the module has respawning encounters, it prevents players from farming cheap XP and leveling with little effort.  Not sure if that's the case here, but it is a quite common way to control challenge.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Yeah, you get experience from quests, not from combat. It takes some getting used to, for sure, but it works.
Make a series of saved games like 1 2 3 and 4, or whatever you want to name them, and save every time there might be some combat soon (for example, before opening a door), cycling through those 4 saves. If combat does indeed happen and doesn't go well, load that save and buff up before proceeding. For more significant events, make a "named" save like you usually do. Also, rest more often to restore those used spells. As you level up and get more buffs, you will become more and more powerful.

That's for the road map back.  Didn't know if you used that, some modification or another altogether.  Magic is fine.  But unless there is either permahaste items or a dpendable stock of speed pots, you are handicapping your toon.  But I did assert that pressure breeds resourcefulness and invention, right?  So go for it.

Max's advice is wrong.  After Cleric 1, the duration of DF's AB boost is increasingly short in comparison.  Once you have access to an extended DF version, THAT's the time to fill up your spell level 2 slots with them.  The +1 divine damage is nice but your first goal is to hit as often as possible as long as possible so that damage has a chance to occur.  If you don't believe me, do some testing in a trainer.  Unless your foes are all dispatched in a single turn, that loss of AB will come back to haunt you.  Bless, Aid, DivFavor, Prayer, Battletide.  These are all "vital" AB buffs for a cleric.  Bless and Aid just happen, together, to raise your AB +2 for 10 times the duration of Prayer/Battletide and at least double the duration of DF after Cleric 1.  Spend fewer rounds rebuffing.  Each of those "time out" rounds your toon will be receiving damage and loosing out on oh-so-precious attack opportunities.

As soon as you pick up your +1 weapon will be the last time you will slot MW.

I had a similar bias towards casting summons.  But all that bias dissipated when I began engaging in encounters that could not be survived without at least a temporary postponement of being focused on by the entire attacking hoard.  Since this campaign just happens to be content where combat XP is not a factor, and especially if you are struggling to solo... summon the help available.  It's part of your divine discipline.  Actually, those skels (i.e. Animate Dead, cleric 6+) are much better helpers because 1) they cannot be critted, feared or dominated and 2) you can buff their weapon (ala MW & darkfire).

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
In the beginning, when you don't have magic armor, a magic shield, or an amulet that boosts AC, the Mage Armor spell gives you +4 AC, which is one of the reasons I like the Magic domain (the other is Stoneskin). Later, when you have those magic items, Mage Armor only gives you 1 Dodge AC which stacks, and the others don't stack, so that is when to stop using Mage Armor. I just looked at my save game from the end of Demon, and I have gauntlets of Haste, so taking Travel for Haste is not needed.

You do not need my permission to change my build when you play it. If you want to make changes to fit your playstyle, feel free, but you risk weakening the build. On the other hand, if you make changes following the advice of someone like Hip, there is not much risk.

Deities have been provided by BioWare because WotC rules list them so they built them in.  Only if the environment specifically controls the influence of deities by custom scripting does it matter at all.  I remember one occasion in HotU, I think it was in the lower dungeon of the Beholder Caves, that OnEnter they scripted some sort of bonus when your cleric prayed to its deity.  I suspect this was intended to involve the influence of a deity more specifically but was never really developed further.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Alright, folks! This topic has been dormant forever, but I'd like to comment on a few things, seeing as my name was mentioned a couple of times.

1- Stag, I build for level 40 power. That's my style, and I rely on my experience as a NWN player to overcome the challenge. You may need to learn a few of my "signature moves" to level my builds less painstaikingly, such as the Taunt / Expertise combo, which AFAIK I'm the only player who knows how to utilize properly (and automatically). As for my Cleric builds, I would recommend that you stick to the leveling strategy portrayed in the guide if you wish to level them up. Clerics are NOT self-buffers until level 7, maybe even level 9, and they NEED you to adopt a different playstyle to succeed. You basically need more long-duration strategies to gain more levels. The Animate Dead / Inflict Wounds strategy (to heal your undead summons) or even Healing Kits (which somehow heal skeletons LOL) are my preferred weapons. If you are playing Cleric as a self-buffer from level 1, you're doing it wrong! Do you think I'd be able to survive with my 8-STR Cleric / Monks if I went toe to toe with the enemy early on? Remember the guide: Embrio Stage is the hardest phase for a Cleric. Don't overestimate your power in the first levels. You're a weakling and should intelligently recognize that and act accordingly :D.

2- Hip, I'm NOT wrong. Bless is absolutely a non-vital buff. You, like Stag above, are playing your Cleric as a level 1 self-buffer, when you could be summoning instead. There's no reason to suffer unnecessarily trying to melee with a level 1-6 Cleric (whose buffs are all at +1 or +2 tops and have insignificant durations) when you can have much stronger beasts doing your bidding for you. After level 7, you'll have A COUPLE of instances of "god mode" per rest with DP / DF, or maybe even just 1, but a Skeleton Warrior buffed with Bull's Strength and Darkfire will still do most of the killing for you. In fact, you can even tank for it with Expertise and lower enemy AC with Taunt while it clears the screen of monsters, Alternatively, you can do the same with a henchman instead of the skelly. The most powerful buffs in the Cleric arsenal are the low-duration ones, and those will only become significant after level 9 (which is also when you get Extended Divine Power). However, you're most likely going to be summoning all the way to level 12 if you play correctly, since you won't be having enough instances of each spell to last you through the day. Of course, if you're playing with no rest restrictions, and you can rest after each encounter, then you might play it that way after level 9. I have tried to play Clerics as self-buffers from the getgo in the past, and that experience has taught me that it's much harder than just summoning and watching things die, especially since you get Animate Dead as a level 3 spell.

3- Low magic settings are where Clerics should shine, however, if this module only goes up to level 11, you won't even get to the best part of playing them which is about level 15 and over. So, if that's the case, then perhaps this module is better played with another type of toon.

Cheers!

Perhaps, when I have the time I'll revisit your cleric guide in more detail now that you've returned from your self-imposed sabatical.  Until then, let's just agree to disagree.  A guide is simply a guide, a nudge towards a productive path.  It's not the Holy Grail.

Stag, don't sell yourself short, brother! You might be getting closer to teenage years now. There's still a long way to go, but the most important thing is that you're moving in the right direction. But let me elaborate on this a bit further, since you like the discussions.

Suppose you encounter a hurdle, right? Well, there are two basic ways to overcome that hurdle. You can:
- Change your build
- Change your in-game approach.

So, if your hurdle is to not be able to open a lock, you can add a few points in Open Lock or you can buy a scroll of Knock and use it. Both get the job done. I have found that trying to compensate the "gimpedness" of a build with intelligent in-game decision making will make you a better player overall. You'll learn new ways to use your toons and that will add to your "repertoire" of moves. Let me give you a practical example:

I was playing Nathyrra on WoG a while back and the Drow were just such a big PITA that I was literally getting annihilated over and over again. Then I switched a couple of spells I had memorized (Invisibility for Darkness) and I began to dominate them like never before. My problem was that, as an Assassin, I would attack the first mage and then the priestesses or secondary mages would have time to cast Time Stop, buff up and kick my ass. But If I cast Darkness just before engaging, the secondary ones wouldn't see me inside the darkness and I'd kill the first Wizard, then stealth again and kill off the rest, going back into the AoE of Darkness every time I needed to re-stealth.

I could, of course, have tried to solve that problem by changing her build. Specifically this one might've been hard to do, but maybe adding SD for HiPS or something similar so I would avoid Dispel.

Same resoning goes to any other problems you can encounter with many different builds. Switching an item could make an unwinnable fight doable (like putting on a death-immunity belt against a necromancer). Most problems you struggle with in-game can be solved in-game. To me, after having played for so long, that's what keeps it challenging and fun.

My strongest builds are tough to play nowadays, because with my improved playstyle, I just trample everything now.

Anyway, I hope this info is useful to you. I was reading my Playing Better guide and remembering what it was like to play the game before knowing what I know now. Have you read it? Maybe in the first part when I describe my journey, you can see part of yours too.

Cheers!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Right, it's been a while, but I'm giving this campaign a proper go now. posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
The NPCs who wont talk to you never will. They are just there to make the town look lived in. As for those other two "quests", if you don't have the right gender or strength, there's nothing you can do, as far as I know.

I am well into Dreamcatcher right now, and haven't returned to the starting town yet.

I am like you, wanting to get maximum experience points.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:

As it is, I've just met Preth and the Red Guards and had to drop a couple of cases of loot near his camp (hopefully for later retrieval). I'm now searching for a suspect scout, but still at level 2. As far as I can tell, I cleared Eureka of all its nasties (although that ghostly voice in the brothel still hasn't gone away). Does that sound about right? Don't get me wrong, my PC is still performing perfectly adequately, it's just that I have no terms of reference.

Thanks

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: If you're playing the same build as me, then you shouldn't have had trouble with that wheel. I didn't. These modules were made way back before the expansion packs, so you can't access the henchman's inventory just like the OC. That map has a merchant (at least somebody you can trade with), so you'll just have to walk there very slowly, once you find him (or as it a her? I honestly forget).

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Sorry, but the wheel beat me (STR 16) 4 times. Odd. The trader is indeed a she, and a very welcome sight.

Now, and I'm embarrassed to 'fess up to this one, I'm in the Fist of the Future temple in Hills' Edge and those damned levers are confounding me. I had initially thought that the Rook/King pieces would be useful, but of course I can't give one to Anera as you state above, so I can't location swap. The only other thought I have left is that the Puzzle Ring I've hung on to from the first part might be beneficial here. Otherwise I'm stuck. Help, please - even if in 'spoiler' form! (That said the old spoiler trick doesn't seem to work in our new home)

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
If I remember correctly...
Put one chess piece in the barrel next to the door you want to open. Then use the lever, and then your remaining chess piece.
If I remember correctly that is.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: That puzzle had me stymied the first time I played this campaign. It didn't occur to me to think of a barrel as a person who could possess a chess piece.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Oh, you are good people - thank you! At least my first thought about the chess pieces wasn't totally wrong - just who/what I gave them to! Was going to do a bit of work now, but instead I'm back to the game - hoorah!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
I finished Dreamcatcher last night and killing the final boss leveled me to level 13.

When I reached level 12, I decided not to take Lingering Song because I thought it was a bit silly to waste a feat on such a weak Bard song. I sat for a long time trying to come up with a better feat to take, and I finally wound up taking Dodge (+1 AC against one opponent). I had considered Weapon Focus: Longbow or Resist Energy (but what kind?) or Skill Focus (but which skill?).

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
That's good info, Empyre - thanks. I've just entered Stonemeet and picked up a couple of quests - and have recently gone up to level 6 and taken my first RDD level. I confess, I swapped taking Blind Fighting for Knockdown (levels 3 and 6), and it proved useful when exiting Skull Gorge. Anyway, back on track now. I've had Anera as my hench/love interest, have you taken her or one of Tiera and Nooble? I just preferred a Cleric over a Rogue, and another front-liner seemed superfluous.

Oh, and I picked up the Half Orc (Og-Hruth?) in Skull Gorge, but he sadly shuffled off this mortal coil when facing the Orc Chieftain. Alas, there was no resurrection option for him, but I noticed that, contrary to previous information, this time I am getting xp for killing stuff, and it does alter according to the number of henchies you're travelling with.

I suspect I've read more into Shadowlords (the first part of the triology) than I should - too much Aielund play, probably - but it's an interesting module, and I'm led to believe that Dramcatcher (the second part) is of significantly higher order.

Cheers

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
I chose Anera again this time. Next time I play this campaign, I plan to be a male cleric, and I'll choose Tiera.

The no-experience-points-for-killing doesn't begin until Dreamcatcher.
